instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
threads.message:
Customer brought in the system stating that he changed the battery and the system did not turn on. 
0.02A and 20v.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR> pin 3 13.03v
f7000 13.076v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.425V

No Water damage. Any help will be appretiate.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Did you try the board alone on the desk, no battery connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.43V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.43V
<SIGNAL>HPWR_EN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.356V
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 5.142V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 20.45V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.46V
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHRGR_R</SIGNAL> - 12.65V
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 5.16V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> - 3.44V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.34
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_POLARIS</SIGNAL> 3.34
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> 3.44
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_T139</SIGNAL> 3.34
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_TBT_T_SW</SIGNAL> 0.02
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_TBT_X_SW</SIGNAL> 0.02

all this are tested alone. on desk no battery

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
threads.message:
"Trigger..."
???
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> goes high at same time too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>  0.02 i unplugged the power and plugged it back still at 0.02

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
threads.message:
I try to be more specific.
"Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>" does NOT mean remove/reconnect charger!
Use pads of SW5200, or <RESISTOR>R5226</RESISTOR>, instead of power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
threads.message:
you mean i should jump the pads on SW5200 or <RESISTOR>R5226</RESISTOR>? sorry not sure exacttly how to do it. 
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a MacBook Pro "Core i7" 2.6 15" Touch/Late 2016). USB C power meter shows 0 amp draw on all ports. No signs of liquid dam
threads.message:
Yes, temporary short between pads.
In fact, solder wire to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and touch any ground point, like a metal shield.
